loans.use: To buy a solar cooker

loans.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex is 35 years old, married and has for the last four years supported his family of eight by selling soft drinks. He earns a monthly income of KES 10,000 and is applying for a loan for KES 20,000 to buy 20 bags of soy drinks to sell to his customers. This is his second loan, which he is applying for after having repaid his first loan fully and on time. He dreams of owning a large store someday and earning enough money to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy 20 bags of soy drinks to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Maram

texts.en:
Maram is a 25-year-old married woman from Madaba, Jordan with three children.

Maram makes dairy products from goat milk and she is requesting a loan of 400 JD to purchase raw materials needed in making these products.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for her project.

loans.name: Zenon

texts.es: El señor Zenón es agricultor y trabaja como mecánico en la ciudad de El Alto y su esposa e hijos lo ayudan con los trabajos de agricultura y producción de tubérculos. Con el dinero del crédito cubrirá el costo de una motobomba así mejorar el riego y la producción de tubérculos. Vive en casa propia ubicada en la localidad de Vicarani en la provincia 	Aroma; es casado y tiene dos hijos. Es la primera vez que el cliente obtiene un crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Zenón is a farmer, but he also works as a mechanic in the city of El Alto. His wife and children help with the farm work and with growing tubers. The money from this loan will cover the cost of a water pump so that he can improve the irrigation and production of tubers. Zenón lives in his own home in the town of Vicarani in Aroma Province. He is married and has two children.

This is the first time he has obtained a loan.

loans.use: to buy a water pump for improving irrigation.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 42 years old and livers in the Saint Paul area. She is married and has five children between 14 and 25 years old. All of them live with her and are presently in school. For the past nineteen years she been selling rice and oil in the local market. Her business helps her to pay her children's school fees. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice and oil  for her business. She hopes to build  a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase rice and oil  for her business.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 33 years old. He lives with his pensioner parents and his wife in Ijevan City.

Since 1996, Robert has been engaged in a clothes trading business with his mother. He rents a stall in the clothes market in Ijevan City. Robert buys clothes in wholesale markets in Yerevan and resells them in his stall in Ijevan City. He sells only men's clothes: suits, trousers, sweaters, and tracksuits. 

This is Robert's second loan from Kiva and third from Nor Horizon. Thanks to his first Kiva loan, Robert increased his business merchandise assortment and made a good profit, which allowed him to buy furniture for his house.
 
Now Robert is seeking a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian dram to buy winter clothes for Christmas and New Year resale.

loans.use: to buy winter clothes for Christmas and New Year resale.

loans.name: Sofiya

texts.ru: София прекрасная хозяйка. Она на воспитании имеет пятерых детей. Муж глава семьи работает колхозником. Семья трудолюбивая. Они все вместе стараются для создания лучших жилищных условий и получения образования. Несмотря на свой возраст она не сидит на месте. На рынке она продает молочные продукты. Она закупает продукцию на селе продает в городе. Её продукция очень востребована. На полученный доход они и живут. Для закупа еще больше товара нужны средства. Поэтому она хочет получить займ в размере 3000 сомони. Она обращается к добрым милосердным людям за помощью. Надеется получить займ и расширить свой товарооборот.
texts.en: Sofiya is a wonderful housewife. She is raising five children. Her husband the head of the family works as a farmer. Their family is hardworking. Together they try to make better living conditions and provide education. Despite her age Sofiya does not sit still. She sells milk products on the market. She buys the products in the village and sells in the town. Her products are in high demand. They spend the profit on daily living. She needs more money to buy more milk products. This is why she wants to take out a loan in the amount of 3000 somoni. Sofiya is asking kind and merciful people for help. She hopes to get the loan and increase the commodity turnaround.

loans.use: to buy milk products.

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié sans enfants.Il exerce dans l'informatique et tient un cybercafé dans sa localité.Il entretient sa petite famille avec les revenus tirés des services qu'il offre à sa clientèle. Pour renforcer son activité, il sollicite un prêt de 200000f pour acheter des accessoires informatiques ( cd, disques dur, écran...).Son ambition est d'élargir son activité aux localité environnantes de sa ville.
texts.en: The borrower is a married man who has no children. He is active in the computing business and has a cybercafé in his town. He looks after his small famiL. with the income he makes from the services he offers to his customers. In order to strengthen his business, he is requesting a loan of 20,000 francs to buy computer accessories (CDs, hard disks, screens..). His ambition is to expand his business to areas surrounding his town.

loans.use: to buy computer accessories (CDs, hard disks, screens..)

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben was born in 1962. He lives in Ijevan city with his family, which consists of his mother, his wife and his three children. Ruben’s mother is a retiree, his wife is a teacher in Ijevan School, his daughters are pupils, and his son attends kindergarten.  
 
In 1986 Ruben graduated from Yerevan State Medical Institute, where he specialized as a therapeutist. He has been working in his specialty till now and simultaneously he has been engaged in animal breeding and land cultivation. He is raising two cows, three calves, some poultry and four bee colonies as well. Also he has a vegetable garden and an orchard. Most of the agricultural produce is used for Ruben's family's needs, but he sells the remainder on-site. With income from his agricultural occupation, Ruben covers part of his family’s needs. 

Ruben is seeking a 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy one more cow and to increase number of his bee colonies.

loans.use: to buy one more cow and to increase the number of his bee colonies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stocks of cereals, sugar, cooking oil, and flour

loans.name: Hellen

texts.es: Hellen de 35 años de edad es un a mujer casada que tiene 3 hijos en las edades de 5 a 10 años, con quienes vive al sur occidente de la ciudad, donde tiene un negocio mediante el cual vende mercancía variada, como ropa femenina y masculina, calzado y accesorios, desde hace 5 años, cuando con el fin de apoyar el bienestar de su hogar, decidió poner en marcha su idea emprendedora, con la que hoy ha logrado su objetivo. Hellen vende a sus clientes mercancías varias, mediante un sistema de crédito distribuido en cuotas, que oscilan entre semanal y mensual,  de acuerdo al plan de pago, que negocia previamente con ellos. Sus principales clientes se encuentran en los alrededores de su barrio y también son empleados de diversas empresas. El sueño  de Hellen, es convertir su negocio en una gran distribuidora de productos,  donde la gente encuentre todo lo que necesita y ella poder vender al por mayor,  a personas  que distribuyen día a día, como lo hace ella hoy. En la actualidad, planea aprovechar la temporada de fiestas de final del año, para aumentar sus ventas y generar mucho mas ingreso, porque sus clientes han hecho pedidos a los cuales desea responder y no tiene el suficiente capital de trabajo para hacerlo. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará adornos navideños, vestidos elegantes, juguetes y calzado, para responder a las solicitudes de sus clientes y darse el gusto de verlos felices y bien elegantes recibiendo el nuevo 2012.
texts.en:
Hellen is 35 years old. She is a married woman and has 3 children who are between 5 and 10 years old. They live southwest of the city where she has a business selling varied merchandise, such as clothing for women and men, shoes and accessories. She decided five years ago, in order to help with the financial welfare of her home, to launch her entrepreneurial plan, which she has successfully done. 

Hellen sells general merchandise to her customers, through a credit system whereby they make payments, ranging from weekly or monthly, according to the payment agreement that she negotiates with them before the sale. Her main customers live around the neighborhood and also are employed by various companies.

Hellen’s dream is to turn her business into a large distributor of products where people find whatever they need and she can sell it at wholesale, for people to resale every day, as she is doing today.

At this time she plans to take advantage of the holiday season at the end of the year to increase her sales and to earn much more income, because her customers have made requests to which she wants to respond but she does not have enough cash flow to do it. This is the reason for which she is asking for a Kiva loan, her first financial funding under the wing of Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, in order to buy Christmas decorations, party dresses, games and shoes in order to respond to the needs of her clients and give herself the pleasure of seeing them happy and very elegant when receiving the 2012 New Year.

loans.use: to buy Christmas decorations, party dresses, toys, and shoes

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité “La Esperanza” se formó con la unión de varias vecinas de una de las comunidades de la ciudad de Santaní. Todas ellas tienen  sus propias actividades, pero también realizan actividades en grupo, para que de esa forma puedan fomentar su compañerismo.
Nilda es una de las integrantes de este grupo, ella al igual que la mayoría de sus compañeras se dedica a la cría y venta de animales, como ser cerdos y pollos. Comenta que su trabajo es muy sacrificado y trabajoso, ya que debe de estar pendiente las 24 hs de sus animales, para que estos estén bien. Su meta es tener una gran granja para poder tener un mayor número de animales.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de lechones y pollitos, para que de esa forma pueda seguir creciendo. Además de eso desea poder comprar alimentos para sus animales. Agradece a la fundación y a Kiva por esta oportunidad de progreso que estas le dan.
texts.en:
The “La Esperanza” (Hope) arose when several neighbors from one of the communities in the city of Santaní joined together.  All of them have their own activities but they also carry out group activities to strengthen their companionship.

Nilda is one of the group members.  Like most of her fellow group members she raises animals like pigs and chickens to sell.   She comments that her work is very demanding and hard because she must be watchful 24 hours a day so that her animals will be well.  Her goal is to have a big farm in order to have a larger amount of animals.

She is asking for the loan to buy piglets and chicks so that she can continue growing.  She also wants to buy feed for her animals.  She thanks the Fundación and Kiva for the opportunity to progress they are giving her.

loans.use: to buy piglets and chicks and feed for them.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is a resident of Litein in South Rift Kenya.  She is married with 6 children who are between the ages of 26 and 11 years old, with the last five still in school.  She has been in farming for 8 years and currently produces maize, milk and eggs for the local market.

Joice has requested a loan of  20,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds and to improve the poultry business.  She says her experience  with poultry farming in the business will boost her income and help her take good care for her family.

She appreciates Juhudi Kilimo for faster loan processing .

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Gajabayani Group

texts.en:
For the development of house hold some extra income is wanted. So one of the women Saraswati from Bargaon located in the M.Rampur, Kalahandi, Odisha, India. Concerned women and her village’s some self dependent women stepped out and decisive to build a secure life for future and their families with their contributions. They formed a group named “Gajabayani” to avail appreciation from Mahashakti Foundation for development of their existing business and develop their social life. Saraswati is the leader of the group who is standing in the front middle person of their group in the photo is Saraswati. 
She has about 46 years old and lives with her husband and only one son. Saraswati’s husband engaged with barber work, since last 9 years. From their occupation the total earning capacity is about Rs.6, 000/- per month. From concerned income, this is not sufficient to maintaining thier family in a smooth way. With this limited earning capacity which is out of maintaining the personal expansion & social livelihood. 
So she planned to borrow the loan from Mahashakti Foundation .Which loan can help to develop herself and her family members as well as can maintain the good social livelihood. After disbursement of loan they will purchase more and more stock on barber items and related items as well as they planned for hire another cabin for saloon which will help her to away from rented cabin. Saraswati wishes to grow her business and save enough to educate her child. 
Other 10 members of the group are also engaged with different Diary, popped rice business, Vegetable, fast-food shop, tailoring and battle shop respectively and they also can improve after loan disbursement.

loans.use: to purchase Mirror, scissors, after save, saving cream, Hair dryer

loans.name: Kosilanta

texts.en:
Kosilanta is 42 years, married with ten children,3 go to school and lives in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She operates a market stall where she deals in buying and selling of rice on top of cocoa trading. She started the business 10 years ago to earn a living where she reaps good profits. She is hard working and plans to expand the business, but faces challenges of competition which affects her returns. 

Kosilanta has requested for a loan to buy rice to sell.

loans.use: to buy rice to sell.

loans.name: Galia

texts.en:
Galia M. is 44 years old. She is single and lives with her old mother and looks after her. Galia is an invalid from birth. One of her legs is shorter than the other. She receives a disablement pension but it is too small and three years ago she has decided to open a stall for coffee, soft drinks and refreshments.

She has the experience because she has worked as a store seller for more then fifteen years. The money she earns of this stall helps her to look after her mother.

Now Galia M. needs $ 500 to supply coffee, soft drinks, mineral water, candies.

loans.use: To supply coffee, soft drinks, mineral water, candies

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: I am a father of 3, aged 34 years. I am a painter. I also take care of my parents.  . I wish to earn more by diversifying and advertising my business to the building industry.

loans.use: Purchase working tools

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a widow and has one grown son. She recently retired from one job, however she was forced to continue working in order to support herself. Eight years ago she decided to start her own business so she could be self-sustainable. By concentrating on a fairly narrow market niche to avoid a head-on collision with bigger competitors, Valentina has developed a successful business selling lightweight bathrobes, pajamas and slippers in the local market. Her inventory is characterized by the finest fabrics, warmth and comfort which attracts many customers to her kiosk.

Valentina trusts the Lord with her venture. She prays often about it and is very committed to its success. Presently, she has about $1,000 in inventory. Her gross revenue is about $1,300 per month and her net profit amounts to around $320 a month.

Valentina has requested a loan for $800 to re-stock her inventory. She would like purchase a good supply of simple, elegant bathrobes and an assortment of slippers that come in a variety of colors and are one-size-fits-all. She is confident that they will sell well and bring her additional income. We believe that Valentina’s flexibility, ability to respond quickly to changes and her knack for providing personalized service will help her continue to succeed in her market.

loans.use: Valentina would like to to re-supply inventory for her lounge-wear store.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr:
Aged 22, Miss Akouvi A. had to abandon the classroom to learn to sew. Her parents left to live on a farm and she has to live in the village with one of her brothers, a master tapestry-maker, in order to pursue her apprenticeship. She has just finished but does not have the means to buy sewing machines and open her own workroom. She is asking for a loan of $600 to buy a sewing machine and rent somewhere to use as a workroom. This will allow her to take advantage of her craft and help her parents.

Agée de 22 ans, Mlle A. Akouvi a du abandonné les bancs pour apprendre la couture. Ses parents sont partis rester dans la ferme pour l’agriculture elle est obligée de rester chez l’un de ses frères de village un maître tapissier afin de poursuivre son apprentissage. Elle vient de terminer et les moyens lui manquent pour s’acheter des machines et ouvrir son atelier. Elle sollicite ce crédit de $600 pour acheter une machine, louer un local qui va lui servir d’atelier. Ceci lui permettra de profiter de son métier et en faire profiter ses parents.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and open a workroom

loans.name: Anarosa

texts.en: Anarosa is 32 years old has three children. She was unemployed until she decided to start her own barbeque business to provide for her family. She enjoys running her own business, because of her skill at cooking and her interest in cuisine. Her first loan of $300 was spent on purchasing the meats needed to run her business. She would like another loan to purchase a gas oven to replace her old charcoal cooker, which would make serving her clients much easier. She is extremely appreciative of the aid she has received that helped her begin her own business.

loans.use: Buying meats for the business.

loans.name: Elvira De Jesus

texts.es:
I have owned a little grocery store for the last 8 years ago. I opened this business when I became jobless. I require the funds in order to buy the following products: rice, sugar, corn, bread, eggs, carbonated beverages, soaps, churros (fried bread) and other items. I am in urgent need of it, since I have to supply my business in order to offer better service to my customers. With my earnings, I support my family since my husband doesn't make much of an income and we have many expenses because of our children.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Yo tengo una pequeña pulperia (grocery store) hace 8 años. Este negocio lo abrí cuando me quede sin trabajo. El dinero lo necesito para hacer las siguientes compras: arroz, azúcar, maíz, pan, huevos, sodas jabones churros y otros. Me urege ya que tengo que surtir mi negocio para dar un mejor servicio a mis clientes. Con las ganancias sostengo a mi familia porque mi esposo gana muy poco y tenemos muchos gastos con nuestros hijos.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, rice, dishwasher soap, quintals of corn, churros (fried bread), cookies, bread and other items.

loans.name: Oghogho

texts.en: Mrs. Oghogho Uyi is 37 years old, is married with six children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells wood (planks) to people. She has been in this business since 1998 and she is requesting a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more wood to sell.

loans.use: Oghogho would like to buy more wood to sell.

loans.name: Yangi

texts.en: Yangi T. is 35 years old and married with four children. She sells rice, sugar and flour in Kabala town of Sierra Leone. She has been selling these items for over ten years now but due to a lack of business capital, she has been unable to improve her business significantly. With her previous loans, Yangi expanded her business to some degree. She is now able to pay her children’s school expenses without difficulty and can meet other family expenses. Yangi would like to earn more profit by diversifying her business and is therefore requesting a loan of $1,000.

loans.use: Diversify her business by selling additional food items to attract new customers

loans.name: Kira B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hasifah N.. She runs a small tailoring business and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to expand her business. Hasifah is 32 years old and a single mother of two children aged 6 and 9. Her children go to school. Each week, Hasifah makes approximately UGX 60,000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her childrens' school fees.

Hasifah has taken a previous loan from BRAC Uganda in the amount of UGX 400,000 to invest it in business and the loan was paid back on time. Hasifah is joined in her small group by Rose N., Sartine K., Agnes O., and Molly N.. Rose N. runs a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase her stock. Sartine K. sells milk and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy more milk cans. Agnes O. runs a salon and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to open another salon in a diferent location. Molly N. sells food in a canteen and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase her stock in the canteen.

loans.use: To expand a tailoring business

loans.name: Nassuti A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane K.. She is currently in the business of farming and is requesting a loan to add to a cattle business. Jane is 42 years old and is married. She has 8 children ranging from age 12 to 28 and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business.

Jane is joined in her small group by Prossy W., Monica M., Ruth M., and Milly N.. Prossy W. has a business in farming and wants to add to the business. Monica M. is currently operating a maize business and wants a loan to purchase more maize. Ruth M. operates a business of selling charcoal and wants to expand to bulk selling. Milly N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth fabric.

loans.use: To purchase more animal feed and purchase more cows

loans.name: Cira Asteria

texts.es:
Ciria Asteria Gómez R. is 53 years old; she studied as far as second grade in primary school. She has six children but only three are still her dependents. She lives in the province of Otuzco, in the department of La Libertad, Perú.

Every Saturday and Sunday she works as a traveling vendor at the Otuzco market, selling vegetables such as: carrots, green onions, coriander and others, as well as medicinal plants and flowers. During the week she works on her farm, where she raises small amounts of grains and potatoes; part of this she consumes and the rest she sells.

She is a member of the "Sagrado Corazón de Jesús" community bank, where she obtained her first loan with which she bought all types of vegetables. With another loan, which will be repaid in four months, she will buy carrots, onions, coriander and flowers.

Her greatest dream is to buy land where she can build a house.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Cira Asteria Gómez R. tiene 53 años de edad, estudio hasta el segundo grado de primaria. Tiene seis hijos en total pero solo tres aun dependen de ella. Vive en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad – Perú.

Ella vende los días sábados y domingos en condición de ambulante en el mercado de Otuzco, vende verduras como: zanahoria, cebolla china, culantro y otros; así también plantas medicinales y flores. Entre semana se dedica a la chacra en la cual cosecha un poco de granos de cereales y papa parte de estos productos los consume y la otra parte los vende.

Es socia del Banco Comunal “Sagrado Corazón de Jesús” lugar donde obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compro verduras de todo tipo. Con el préstamo de S/. 400.00 el cual lo pagara en un periodo de cuatro meses comprará 4 arrobas de zanahoria, dos cientos de cebolla, un paquete de culantro y también flores.

Su mayor sueño es comprar un terreno para construir su casa.

loans.use: Purchase carrots, onions, etc. to sell

loans.name: Cristo Vive Group

texts.en:
Miline Palveuts is a 25 year-old woman who lives with her 5 children (ages: 9, 7, 6, 4, 6 months) and husband in the small community of Imbert in the Dominican Republic. To support her family, Miline sells used clothing in the street. She is on her feet 10 hours a day, which is exhausting. Miline hopes that one day she'll be able to afford to rent a store near her home.

That is why Miline and 14 other women--all of who emigrated form Haiti in the hopes of finding a better life--have applied for a collective loan of $2,225 U.S. dollars.

In her free time, Miline enjoys going to church and reading her Bible. The entire group would like to thank every Kiva lender and tell them God bless.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Martha Lorena M. is a very hardworking woman, dedicating herself to her agricultural business for several years now with the aim of improving her living conditions and concurrently provide a better education for her three school-aged children.

Since she started her business, she has always had in mind improving her status of living and investing to generate a better income for her children who hope to continue their studies.

The need she currently has occurred because she does not have electricity in her home, given that she lives in a very isolated area. For this reason, she has reached out to CEPRODEL for assistance in obtaining a loan to pay for installation of a solar panel. Upon receipt of the loan, she must be very responsible and cancel her debt so that she can get ahead along with her kids who rely on her a great deal.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Martha Lorena M. es una mujer muy esforzada en su negocio agropecuario dedicándose a esta labor desde hace varios años con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de su hogar y de igual manera de brindarles las mejores condiciones de estudio a sus tres hijos en edad escolar.

Desde que inició su labor siempre ha tenido en mente mejorar su status de vida invirtiendo para obtener mejores ingresos para sus hijos con el propósito de que logren estudiar.

La necesidad que actualmente atraviesa es que no posee energía eléctrica en su hogar por vivir en una zona muy alejada. Por esta razón es que ha solicitado apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito oportuno para el pago del panel solar debido que al haberlo obtenido tiene que ser muy responsable y cancelar esta deuda para que de esta manera logre salir adelante junto con sus hijos que tanto necesitan de ella.

loans.use: Pay for a solar panel for her home.

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en: Pepe L., 44, is married with 6 children.  She has 3 year(s) of experience in the barbeque foods business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has had 5 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Pepe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also use the loan for home improvement by buying cement, timber and an iron roof. Her husband also works to help out with the family  needs.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and materials needed for food production such as meats and vegetables.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is 56 years old and lives with his wife and four children in a town close to Saida, in the south of Lebanon. He owns a grocery store and has been a microcredit client of Al Majmoua for the past five years.

Mohamad is a very ambitious and motivated man. With the help of previous loans, he gradually expanded his business. He used the first loan of $1200 to purchase more goods for his shop. The second loan was to purchase a new truck to sell potatoes. Presently, he needs $700 to purchase a stock of juice bottles. Indeed, during the summer season there is an increased demand for such products and he needs to pay for the increase in inventory in cash to the supplier.

loans.use: To purchase stock of juice bottles

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly M. is 44 years old and lives with her father. She makes bricks to sell from her house. She works hard at her business and earns approximately US$5.96 per day. She is single and started her business in 2000. Her father is a rice farmer. She lives in Kean Sangkei Commune, Siem Reap Province.

Ly thought about her lack of capital to use for her business. She decided to request a loan of US$800 to stock clay for making bricks and to buy gas and wood to operate her business. The loan will increase her income, which will help her support her family and sufficiently cover their living expenses.

loans.use: To stock clay to make bricks and to buy gas and wood to operate her business

loans.name: Raufjon

texts.en:
Raufjon M. is 31 years old. He is married and has two children. Raufjon is a selfless father, and as a good head of household, he has in mind what he should do to support his family.

He decided to dedicate himself to raising livestock three years ago. He added everything he learned to the education his parents had instilled in him since he was a child. He plans to keep raising livestock and to acquire even more. This is why he is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) that will allow him to purchase more fodder for the normal development and competitiveness of his cattle. He promises to repay the loan in 12 months. He thanks all of you who kindly respond to his request.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Sebastián

texts.es:
Al contar con 15 años de experiencia en la crianza y venta de chanchos, el señor Sebastián tiene más de 30 casado (su esposa es la que sale en la foto), junto con ella se ha propuesto conseguir una calidad de vida adecuada para sus próximos años puesto que su única hija ya está casada y en el mismo negocio independientemente. Con su vida entera dedicada al negocio y, a eventuales trabajos de carpintería y construcción, no le alcanza para tener un estilo de vida regular siquiera, pero la venidera temporada navideña le abren las puertas de la esperanza.

Debido a la alta demanda de lechones (chanchos pequeños, de entre 0 y 6 meses) por dicha campaña, es que requiere de 700 soles para poder financiar el alimento de sus lechones y poder venderlos a un precio justo para su inversión.
texts.en:
With 15 years of experience in raising and selling pigs, Sebastian has been married for over 30 (his wife is the one in this photo). Together, the couple work to achieve an appropriate quality of life for themselves over the upcoming years, due to the fact that their only daughter is now married and has her own business in this field. Sebastian has worked his entire life, raising pigs and doing odd jobs like carpentry and construction, but he has not yet achieved a normal standard of living. However, the upcoming Christmas season opens the doors of hope. Due to the high demand for piglets (between zero and six months old) during this season, Sebastian needs 700 soles to finance the food for his piglets and sell them at a fair price for his investment.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in pig food and sales to prepare for the Christmas season

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is married and has 4 dependents. She has received a junior high education. Her husband is a military officer.

Grace sells charcoal, which is a popular fuel for those who cannot afford to buy gas. She sells the charcoal at a place popularly called Air Force, near Shama. She has been selling charcoal since 1994. She is responsible for paying the family's utility bills and other expenses.

Grace will use her loan to buy more charcoal for sale, since demand for it is very high. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale, since demand is very high.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 41years old and is married with 6 children. She sells food and soup ingredients such as rice, beans, palm oil, melon seeds, and crayfish. She started this business in 2002. 

She needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more food and soup ingredients to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ny Eam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people in Chamka village in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia, have formed a village bank loan group and Mrs. Ny E. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. S. Rom, is a palm juice collector who gathers juice to process into palm sugar or wine. He now wants to expand his business, and so Mrs. Ny E. decided to ask for a loan to buy more containers for the palm juice. She is 52 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.  
	
Twelve members in this group will receive End-of-Term (EoT) loans and the rest will have monthly payment loans. In EoT loans, payment on principal is not required until the very end of the loan term but is allowed at any time that the borrower is able to make such a payment. The EoT loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. Most clients start to make principal payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy palm juice containers.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Fifty-nine year old Alice is married to Michael Anyeh and they have eight children all older than fifteen. Alice decided to work extra hard to assist her husband in bringing up these children, but along the way she encountered some challenges such as death and ill health. She saw GHAPE as an opportunity to assist her in improving her livelihood. She was trained and given a loan in 2004.
 
This will be Alice's fourth loan from GHAPE; she became a member in 2004. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location (right on the main road), the quality of her products, and her reasonable prices. She buys in bulk which causes the price to be minimal and her children help her in caring for the pigs. She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales.

She plans to use the loan to buy tomatoes, spices, palm oil, piglets, and repair her old pig stye. She plans to use the profit from the loan to further her children's education in higher institutions of learning. This business of Alice's will help her community by supplying food to them and will also help those in her community to reduce their distance to the market to buy the type of goods she is selling.

Alice prefers to receive a loan from GHAPE because the method of repayment is comfortable and convenient, and because of the social services and training GHAPE also offers.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, spices, palm oil and piglets.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: Gloria tiene 41 años, vive con sus dos hijos, pues está separada de su pareja. De joven estudió cosmetología y al concluir sus estudios instaló un centro de belleza en el mercado de su ciudad, donde viene trabajando desde hace 7 años, gracias a la gran diversidad de productos de belleza que ofrece en  este mercado, las personas nunca dejan de visitarla al realizar sus compras. Gloria trabaja todas las mañanas haciendo maquillajes y peinados, que es lo que más disfruta, sobre todo a fin de año por la cantidad de fiestas escolares que hay en la ciudad, generando mayores ganancias. Pero lo que no le gusta realizar son los cortes para varones porque no son creativos, a diferencia de los peinados de las mujeres. Ella  está dispuesta a instalar un salón de belleza en su casa y así dejar de pagar el alquiler del local, dinero que invertiría en la ambientación de su propio local. Gloria viene trabajando junto a PRISMA 7 años, tiempo que le ayudó a reforzar su capital de trabajo y entrelazar lazos de amistad con las socias de su grupo. Con los 2 mil soles desea comprar materiales para equipar su negocio con lo último en tecnología y hacerlo más competitivo.
texts.en:
Gloria is 41 years old. She lives with her two children, and is separated from her husband. As a young woman, she studied cosmetology and at the end of her studies she got a spot in a beauty salon in the market in her city, where she has worked for 7 years. Thanks to the great diversity of beauty products that she offers in the market, the people never stop coming to make purchases from her. Gloria works every morning making combs and brushes, and she really enjoys this, above all during the end of the year because of the number of school parties that there are in the city, which generate a larger income. But she doesn’t enjoy doing haircuts for the men because they are not creative, as compared to the haircuts for the women. She wants to install a beauty salon in her home and so stop paying rent for her location, money which she would invest in the ambiance of her own shop. Gloria has been working with PRISMA for 7 years, time that has helped her reinforce her working capital and enter into friendships with the members of her group. With the 2000 soles, she wants to buy materials to equip her store with the latest technology and make it more competitive.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools for her salon

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en: Juanita C. is from Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, in the Philippines.  She is married and 62 years old. Her husband is a barangay, or village, councilor. She was attracted to the programs and services provided by Paglaum, Kiva's partner, and immediately applied for membership.  By being a member, one earns many benefits especially on insurance and access to loans. Recently, Mrs. C. applied for a loan to buy a new fishing boat and to obtain additional capital for her fish vending business. She hopes to earn extra income for herself and her husband.

loans.use: to buy a new fishing boat and to acquire capital for fish selling

loans.name: Massouko

texts.fr:
Massouko D. est une veuve de 60 ans qui vit avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants chez son défunt mari à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’initia très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente  de pagnes wax, de bracelets, de  tissus brodés,  de draps de lit, de colliers  pour enfants etc. Massouko évolue dans ce créneau depuis maintenant trente ans. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six  ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association JIGUISSEME de Sanoubougou I), elle est à son 7ème prêt individuel et  tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 10 complets de tissus brodés, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 60 draps de qualités différentes et des centaines de colliers  pour enfants. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) ensuite elle les revend chez elle et  de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes, en détail au comptant et quelques à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Massouko D. is a 60-year-old widow who lives with her co-wife and their children in the home of her late husband in Sanoubougou I, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to attend school for societal reasons, she soon got introduced to income-generating work, notably buying and selling Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), bracelets, embroidered fabrics, bed sheets, necklaces for children, etc. Massouko has been improving in her niche market for thirty years now.

Wanting to do better in satisfying her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over six years ago. After four solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area (Association JIGUISSEME de Sanoubougou I), she is now on her seventh individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, she plans to buy 10 outfits of embroidered fabrics, 10 bolts of Wax pagnes, 60 bed sheets of different grades, and a hundred-some necklaces for children. Supplies of goods are gotten in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and then are sold at home or door-to-door to customers composed generally of women, cash accepted and credit at times.

She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Nishongul

texts.ru: Турсунова Нишонгуль- женщина 49 лет. Мать 5-х детей. Нишонгуль занимается, со своей семьей переработкой пряжи вязанием шерстяных носков Ей помогают невестка и дочери. Нишонгуль реализует свой товар в городке Адрасмане, джамоате Мархамате и в городе  Худжанде. У нее имеют надежные клиенты, у которых всегда большой спрос. Нишонгуль хочет закупить оптом пряжу на полученный займ.
texts.en:
Nishongul T. is 49 years old and has 5 children. She knits wool socks for sale, working together with her family. She gets help from her daughters and her daughter in-law. Nishongul sells her stock in the towns of Adrasman, Marchamat and Hudzhande. She has a solid client base with a large demand. Nishongul would like to use the loan to buy wholesale knitting wool.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wholesale knitting wool

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To prepare and sell food

loans.name: Scholastica Adhiambo

texts.en:
Scholastica Adhiambo O. is a 32-year-old mother of two children, ages 11 and one, and is married to a businessman. Her family lives in Nyalenda slum in Kisumu. She sells new clothing, purchased from Kampala in the town center at Lake Market. On average, she sees four to five customers a day. She hopes to use the loan to purchase more clothes to stock her shop with.

Scholastica's main challenge is a lack of customers because citizens here in Kisumu are facing hard economic times. Scholastica says August to September are the times when she sells the most clothes. She likes running her own business because she is able to do things herself and nobody controls her. When asked who makes better entrepreneurs, men or women, she says women. This is a common answer, even from the men here in Kisumu because, as Scholastica says, the women care more for the children.

In this video, you can hear me greet Scholastica saying "Idhi Nade", which is Luo for "How are you?" Scholastica responds, "Adhi maber," meaning "very good." Most people living in Kisumu descend from the Luo tribe, the same tribe as Obama's father. At the end, you will hear me fluctuate between Kiswahili and Luo saying "Asante Sana" in Kiswahili, meaning "thank you" and "Erokamano", which in Luo means "thank you." The voices you hear in the background are people coming for a weekly K-MET borrower meeting. To see what one looks like, check out the first video in this blog post.

K-MET, the NGO distributing the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development corporation focused on raising health standards in Kenya. You can read more about K-MET’s work here.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing stock.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan T. is a villager who has an occupation raising pigs. She has had a small pigpen next to her house for nine years and she can raise at least two litters a year. In addition, she sells a few cakes to her neighbors in the village for additional profit. 
She is married to Cheang Choun (he is shown in the picture), who drives a motorbike taxi. Recently, Chan T.'s husband can't generate as much revenue as before because his motor is not attractive to his clients. Therefore, Chan T. has decided to ask for a loan to replace her husband's old motor.

loans.use: To replace her husband's old motor

loans.name: Princess

texts.en:
Princess R. is only 19 years old, yet she is strong and determined to find a way to raise herself up from poverty. She lives with her partner, Rommel, who is a 29-year-old fisherman. They plan to get married soon. Together, they have one child.

She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Since she has an 11-month-old baby and is still taking care of it, she proposes a loan of 10,000 pesos to pay for the stock and groceries that she will be selling in her sari-sari store (general store). The store will surely be the center of the neighbors’ eyes since they can buy most basic needs/groceries in it.

She is optimistic that in the near future she can convert her store into a grocery store and be able to save for her child’s education.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store (general store)

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen C. is from the town of Roxas. She is 46 years old. Aileen is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Aileen owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Aileen has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Aileen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aileen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock to raise & sell in the future. Aileen is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Aileen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn M. is from the village of Lawis Panalsalan. She is 42 years old. Marilyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora is thirty – three years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters who are all still in school. She works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. Dora lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. She is a trader. She is into palm oil production business. Dora supplies to retailers in her community. She procures the palm fruits from nearby communities. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy palm fruits in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea C., 49, is homemaker. She stays at home to care for her two children, and holds a daily routine as well. Her husband provides for the family’s expenses with his income as a domestic statue carver. He buys a piece of wood and then carves it into formal statues. He also sells his finished items to people who need to decorate and charm their house. Recently, he ran out of raw material from his stock supply. This has caused frequent interruption to his operations. Therefore, Chea C. would like a loan of US$700 to be used to buy wood and some carving tools for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy wood and some carving tools for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Nahid

texts.en:
Nahid is married and has five children. She is a teacher. Her husband is an assistant chef in Jerusalem. Currently, they live in a rented house. With their savings, they were able to buy a small apartment, but they need to finish it immediately to move to it before winter starts, because their rented house is not appropriate. 

Nahid approached FATEN for a loan to finance some of the last urgent finishing issues in their new house. She requested $1500 USD.

Nahid appears in the picture at her office in the school where she teaches.

loans.use: Housing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase pregnant cows to increase income

loans.name: Airen Musimbi

texts.en:
Airen is 56 years old, married and blessed with three children. She sells clothing at Mbururu in Eldoret.

She was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by a neighbor. She is planning to use the loan she is taking from KADET to buy more stock of clothing for both adults and children. Her future dream is to buy a plot of land and construct rental houses.

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more clothing (adult and child sizes) to sell to customers

loans.name: Cosmas Ogola

texts.en:
Cosmas Ogola O. owns the Nyatike Emporium where he has been making and selling shoes for 16 years. He has three employees and his business is located in the Kangemi market. His challenges are too few customers and lack of funds. He is using this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy leather materials for making more shoes and soles. In the future, he want to expand his business and educate all his children. 
Cosmas is married and has three children. He describes himself as respectful and hardworking. He is the chairman of a TSS group.

loans.use: To buy leather materials and soles

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 25 years old and married with a child. She sells eggs. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She assists her husband in the family. She is very hardworking and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. She plans to add livestock sales to her business. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more eggs and livestock. With this kind of business, she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to provide better for her children's education. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs to sell

loans.name: Pelepesite

texts.en:
Pelepesite P. is 45 and married with 5 children (ages 4-19).  She owns a business venture, selling baked goods in the local community.  Pelepesite has 3 years of experience in this business.  Pelepesite needs a loan of WST $2500 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Pelepesite joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Pelepesite's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Pelepesite are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:              2 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15"

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Maria Maximina

texts.es: La señora Maximina está solicitando un nuevo crédito para invertirlo en su negocio que es comercialización de verduras, ella vende los productos en la Paz Centro, León y  Managua  de lunes a viernes, por lo que de alguna u otra forma busca la manera de proporcionarle a su familia el pan de cada día para ella y su familia. Por lo que siempre ha luchado para mejorar sus ingresos ya que no es fácil mantener este negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de materia prima. Su deseo es proporcionar estabilidad a su familia y mantener activo su negocio.
texts.en:
Señora Maximina is seeking a new loan to invest in her business, which is selling vegetables. She sells these products in central La Paz, León, and Managua from Monday to Friday. Through these sales, in one way or another, she seeks a way to provide daily sustenance for herself and her family. She has always struggled to increase her income, since it is not easy to maintain this business. The financing that she is asking for is working capital for the purchase of basic goods. Her goal is to provide stability for her family and keep her business active.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Chhoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Chhoeun P. is 25 years old and lives in Tuol Svay village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Phally Oeng, are farmers who own a two-hectare field to cultivate rice. They face some problems because their field does not have enough water and the soil is infertile. Thus, Mrs. Chhoeun P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the rice field. Mrs. Chhoeun P. is a mother of two children who are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Rosita's Group

texts.en: Rosita A. is from the town of Usol Jones, Isabela. She is 41 years old and is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosita A.. Rosita is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. Rosita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sulemani

texts.en:
Sulemani F. Y. is married and has three children. She has received junior high education.  Sulemani F. sells cosmetics and provisions at Elmina, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a nurse.  

Sulemani F. uses her income to help her husband in the payment of utility bills and school fees. Sulemani F. will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics and provisions for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sulemani F. plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: purchase more cosmetics and provisions for sale

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo sells groceries, foodstuffs and drinks. Her shop is sited at the front of her house and she has been in this business for over twenty years. She does this business to make a living in Lagos. She supports her husband with the profit from the business to meet her family needs – feeding, clothing, etc.

Taiwo is 42 years old and is married with four children: three female and one male. She lives in Lagos with her family. She hopes that her business grows and expands into a bigger shop in future.

Taiwo hopes for the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks and groceries like assorted biscuits, tea, sachet milk and bread as well as foodstuffs like garri, palm oil, and groundnut (peanut) oil. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their wonderful assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is married with four children. She is 36 years old. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports their family. Rebecca is a trader; she sells groceries, drinks and cooking oil. She has been running this business for 5 years. Rebecca needs a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says a big thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Tupanka

texts.en:
Tupanka is a 42-year-old married lady with three children. She has been selling clothes to local community residents for ten years. She also sells cultural products to earn extra income. Her husband is a businessman and they work hard to improve their standard of living. 

Tupanka plans to expand her business in the future. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Silva

texts.pt:
Silva Ernesto C. nasceu no Distrito de Chokwe, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 35 anos de idade, casado e pai de 3 filhos de 14, 10 e 05 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez 12ą classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta seus pais que vivem com ele.
Saiu de Chokwe para Maputo no Distrito de Boane ainda muito jovem, tendo estudado e crescer nesta zona, onde vive actualmente. Trabalha na empresa de segurança G4S ha mais de 6 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e tem um salário de 4.375.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta Bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 23.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (loiça sanitária, cimento e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 9.000.00mt e 13.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para continuar com a melhoria da sua casa e abrir um salão de cabeleireiro como forma de aumentar a receita familiar.
texts.en:
Silva Ernesto C. was born in the district of Chokwe, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 35 years old, married, and has 3 children ages 14, 10 and 5. All attend school. He attended school through the 12th grade but did not continue due to a lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family, and supports his parents who live with him. He left Chokwe for the Boane district of Maputo when he was still very young. He attended school and grew up there, and still lives in this area. He has worked for the security company G4S for more than 6 years. He does not have any employees and receives a salary of 4.375.00 mt per month, which he uses for household expenses and saves a bit in his bank account. He has never had loans in other banks. He learned about Hluvuku thorugh work colleagues who are also Hluvuku customers. This is his third loan, in the amount of 23.000.00mt which he will use to purchase construction material (porcelain bath fixtures, cement, etc.) to continue building his home. The prior loans were for 9.000.00mt and 13.000.00mt for the same purpose. He promises to pay this loan as agreed in order to have access to others. In the future he plans to request more loans to continue his home improvements and to open a hair salon as a way to increase his family's income.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of construciton materials (poreclain bath fixtures, cement, etc. )

loans.name: Narcisa's Group

texts.en:
Narcisa M. is from the village of Sta Isabel Norte. She is 42 years old. Narcisa is the group leader of a 21-member group taking out a loan from ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Narcisa M.' Group.

Narcisa is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Narcisa owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Narcisa is just starting this business.

In 2009, Narcisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Narcisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Narcisa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers

loans.name: Siv's Group

texts.en:
This group loan which consists of four people is located in Cheung Prey Bei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Siv S. is 38 years old and is the leader of the group loan, having been selected by its members. Each member of this group loan will use their share to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Siv S. is a fruit seller and her husband, Mr. Noun Neal, is a motorbike taxi driver. With both these businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family. For her fruit business, Mrs. Siv S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit to expand her business activities. 

This couple has three children; two are students in the local school while the youngest one is only a year old.

loans.use: To buy more fruit

loans.name: Mawuko Adakou

texts.fr:
Agée de 57 ans, G. adakou mawuko demeure très active. Elle tient une boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle y vend différents produits tels que savon de marseille, sacs de riz, boites de conserves, de lait.
Avec le prêt demandé, elle envisage acheter des cartons de savons, de sardines et de riz pour soutenir les besoins de sa clientèle.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
G. Adakou Mawuko is an active 57 year-old. She owns a shop that sells general foods, such as Marseille soap, bags of rice, jars of jam, and milk. She aims to use the loan in order to purchase boxes of soap, sardines, and rice in order to meet her customers' demand. She is married with one child.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of general foods

loans.name: Straton

texts.fr: M. Straton est un jeune célibataire de 28 ans, née en district Bugesera  de la province de l’Est du Rwanda, son niveau d’étude est 4  années de secondaire.  Il est commençant de détail en boutique. Il contracte un prêt pour une balance pour pouvoir peser le poids de grande quantité pour ses clients. Il a besoin à acheter des facturiers et un cachet en vue de gagner les clients de grande consommation, car c’est une obligation du gouvernement Rwandais à tous vendeurs de donner aux acheteurs une facture cacheté. Il a ouvert un compte dans Amasezerano Community Banking   depuis septembre 2008, avec ce prêt il veut augmenter les épargnes afin de construire la maison d’habitation, l’augmentation de son chiffre d’affaires  lui permettra de se marier et devenir grossiste dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
Straton M. is a 28 year old single young man born in the Bugesera district of Rwanda’s Eastern Province. He completed 4 years of secondary school. He is a retailer in a small shop. He has taken out a loan to buy a scale in order to be able to weigh large quantities for his customers. He needs to purchase invoice books and a stamp in order to win large customers, as the government of Rwanda requires sellers to deliver a stamped invoice to buyers. He opened an account at Amasezerano Community Banking in September 2008. With this loan, he intends to increase his savings in order to build a house. The increase in sales will enable him to get married and become a wholesaler in the future.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a scale, invoice books and a stamp

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato U. is from the village of Minsapinit, Gingoog City. He is 38 years old. Renato is widowed and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Renato owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Renato has been engaged in his business for over 1 years and earns approximately 9500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Renato joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Renato has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Renato is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Renato from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Jambu's Group

texts.en:
Jambu A. is the leader of her group. She is 38 and divorced. She has a daughter and a son. The son is at school and the daughter is not yet in school. In order to make money Jambu prepares and sells various dishes at the market. In this way, she earns 4,000 soms per month. She is also engaged in cattle breeding.  With money received from the loan, Jambu wants to purchase two cows to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle, open her own cafeteria and build a shed for cattle.

Manzurahon J., 24, is married.  She has a daughter and a son; both of them are preschool age (under 7).  Manzurahon works in a bakery and her husband is a taxi driver. Manzurahon earns 8,000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a vehicle for her husband. Manzurahon wants to sell her husband’s vehicle, add some money which she saved and purchase another car. But she doesn’t have enough money, so she hopes to obtain the loan.

Mamatkamil I., 55, is married. He has six children; the older daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second daughter and the older son went to work in Russia and the other children are at school.  Mamatkamil and his wife are engaged in farming. They own some land, so they cultivate various fruits and vegetables. By selling some part of the harvest, Mamatkamil makes 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase fertilizers which are needed for farming.  In the near future, he plans to start repairing his house.

Burulkan M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 52 and married. She has two daughter and two sons; the first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second daughter and the older son went to work in Russia and the youngest son is at school. Two years ago with the initial investment of 7,000 soms,  Burulkan started to breed cattle. Her husband works in construction; he earns 5,000 soms per month. When he is free, he helps his wife with her activity. With money received from the loan, Burulkan wants to start building a shed for cattle. 

,--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for breeding

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen, 40 years old, is married to M. B.. They are both very talented and hardworking people. They are involved in a shoe making business. They receive orders from shoe shops and shoe factories and by completing them, they earn a good profit. They have been doing this work for the past seven years. They are very good-natured people who always try to keep everyone happy in their surroundings.

Parveen and her husband own a small house of two rooms in the city of Kasur (famous for its sweetmeats) in Pakistan where they have been living for past eight years. They started this work after spending a year in this city and have developed a good reputation among their customers. They have applied for a loan from Asasah in order to buy raw materials such as leather, nails, and shoe polishers in bulk. This investment in their business will help them to complete their larger orders on time and to earn a good income. Parveen is a regular lender with Asasah and is in her 3rd loan cycle. In previous loan years, she never missed a meeting and always paid her installments on time.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for a shoe making business

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas, 36 years old, is a married father of two children, ages 8 and 14, both of whom attend school. Thomas has been farming for the last 15 years in Kisii town, western Kenya, and employs two farmhands. His mixed farm produces maize, nappier grass and milk which he sells locally. He is also a carpenter.

Thomas has requested this loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He faces the challenge of lack of finances to expand his businesses and irregular cash flows from the sale of milk. Despite the challenges he hopes to open a carpentry workshop and acquire more dairy cows in the future. He says that the income from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children and develop more businesses that will increase the income of his family. 

Thomas is thanking Juhudi for the support and requests the interest rates be reduced.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Hasankhon

texts.en: Hasankhon is a hard-working farmer because he knows that the only way he can support and provide for his loved ones is through hard work and dedication. Consequently, he leaves home every day at dawn to work on his farm and to look after his cattle. Hasankhon wishes to expand his business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and young cattle. That is the reason that he is asking for a loan. He will always cherish the memory of all those who gave him a helping hand when he needed it by granting him his request. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.
